posts.name: smclean1969
posts.cooked: I wanted to see what some of the FTC teams have recently been using for linear slides.  We‚Äôre finding some that are very expensive (hundreds of dollars) or not quite what we‚Äôre looking for in terms of sizing.  I‚Äôve seen some teams that have multi-stage slides but I can‚Äôt seem to find them online.  thanks, Scott Lead Mentor FTC 16253, BEAST Robotics Colorado Springs, CO

posts.cooked: I would recommend taking a look at Rev‚Äôs UltraSlide they come in two different lengths. Also check out Long Robotics Slides The Long Robotics slides are very similar to the Misumi slides . Misumi also has a multi stage

posts.name: Nick Aarestad
posts.cooked:
And to round out the FTC supplier list, Gobilda recently announced these: Steel Viper-Slide (14-Ball Carriage, 336mm Length, 244mm Travel) - goBILDA

and has a few other linear-type products.

I would say that running a lot of linear slides on a robot does add up pretty quick. I think we hit a robot with like $600 of Misumi slides on it one year.

posts.cooked: First recommending ultraslides and then mentioning LR/misumi slides is like first recommending an 8020 lift kit before mentioning the greyt elevator exists

posts.name: wgorgen
posts.cooked:
cadandcookies:

And to round out the FTC supplier list, Gobilda recently announced these: Steel Viper-Slide (14-Ball Carriage, 336mm Length, 244mm Travel) - goBILDA

Wait - is that literally a drawer slide ? I was going to mention that drawer slides have been used in the past but figured that I would look and see what new products are out there‚Ä¶

This is not meant to disparage GoBilda as I love their products. But that seriously looks like they are just re-selling a Home Depot part. But the fact that they have integrated their other parts to fit it to turn it into a useful linear slide mechanism is great!

posts.name: Nick Aarestad
posts.cooked: Yeah my understanding is that they may have some some amount of speccing to make it nice to work with their 4mm ecosystem, but mostly it‚Äôs the related parts that are the real winner there.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
wgorgen:

Wait - is that literally a drawer slide

Yes, I‚Äôve used those for FRC slides before, and thought about mentioning them.  They weren‚Äôt really up to the FRC tasks, but the ones I‚Äôd used seemed a bit too large and difficult to adapt to FTC to recommend.

posts.name: guineawheek
posts.cooked:
The entire ftc linear extension meta for the past decade has been various forms of figuring out how to use better drawer slides. The integration alone is worth the price of admission.

Home Depot slides used to be a very popular solution, but, as you can tell just from this thread, they‚Äôre pretty bulky, so teams have largely moved away from them.

Misumi slides are competitive, but often require design work to integrate well.

LR slides are more ‚Äúbatteries included‚Äù with a guide of how to make 3dp inserts, but this, of course, assumes you have a printer (which nowadays is close to a ‚Äúmust‚Äù anyway).

Rev‚Äôs slide solutions to date are nowhere near as good as the above for the average team. Teams have made them Championship-winning competitive but only with significantly more effort and work than Misumi or the LR solutions would provide. (In particular, nobody sets up those slides the way Rev intends you to setup those slides, and the optimal configuration teams like Gluten Free used involved sliders from a previous version of their slide kit they likely no longer sell.)

The hope with Gobilda‚Äôs entry is that it will be a fully integrated solution into the best COTS kit for FTC, that will be competitive with the Misumi/LR entries and with only parts buyable from their website. A fully COTS entry for linear extensions, which have been a fairly prominent feature of 9 of the past 10 games. So yeah, it‚Äôs just a ‚Äúdrawer slide‚Äù, but the details of the drawer slide are what make it valuable.
